School of Advanced Manufacturing Fuzhou University Jinjiang 362251 China Graphical abstract The CuMgZrOx oxide catalysts were employed with economical 2-PrOH as the hydrogen donor for catalytic transfer hydrogenation of ethyl levulinate (EL) to γ-valerolactone (GVL). The cost-effective Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst exhibited excellent physicochemical properties, with 99.8% EL conversion and 88.0% GVL yield. Studies have shown that sufficient basic sites of the catalyst, along with the maintenance of the Cu2+/Cu+ state rather than Cu0, are crucial for achieving high GVL yields. Optimization of the substrate-to-hydrogen donor ratio (1:3), along with recycling tests and characterization, demonstrated excellent activity (99.5% EL conversion and 90.0% GVL yield) and cycle stability for the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst, highlighting its strong potential for practical applications. The mechanism for GVL production from EL via the metal hydride as the dominant route was proposed based on rigorous experimental studies and in-depth characterization. Substrate scope evaluation showed that the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst also exhibited outstanding activity in converting methyl levulinate and butyl levulinate to GVL. Keywords CuMgZrOx Levulinate esters Metal hydride route γ-Valerolactone Stability Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The escalating global demand for energy has resulted in significant environmental impacts and challenges to energy sustainability [1,2]. The transition from traditional fossil fuels to renewable energy sources is particularly critical [3,4]. Biomass, known for its renewability, wide availability, abundant reserves, and cost-effectiveness, presents a viable alternative [3,5]. Levulinic acid (LA), a key biomass-derived chemical, has attracted attention due to its potential for producing value-added products. Among these, γ-valerolactone (GVL) is especially noteworthy. Recognized for its versatility, GVL is a promising candidate for use in green solvents and as a precursor for bio-based materials [6,7]. This has led to a surge in research on the efficient transformation of LA to GVL, emphasizing the importance of this pathway in advancing renewable energy conversion [8,9]. Ethyl levulinate (EL), which shares chemical similarities with LA, is increasingly used in the hydrogenation-based transformation of GVL [10]. EL is primarily produced through the alcoholysis of carbohydrates such as sucrose, glucose, and cellulose, and less frequently from 5-(Chloromethyl)furfural, furfuryl alcohol, and LA [11,12]. In contrast, LA is mainly produced via carbohydrate hydrolysis [13]. Compared to hydrolysis, the alcoholysis method significantly reduces the formation of humins and enhances EL yield [14]. Moreover, EL has a lower boiling point and lacks the acidic properties of LA, making it advantageous for improving catalyst stability and reducing reactor corrosion. Thus, EL presents a more practical alternative for GVL transformation. H2 is one of the most commonly used hydrogen donors for the transformation of GVL from EL (Table S1, Entries 1–16) [15,16]. In catalytic systems where H2 serves as the hydrogen source, its low solubility in most solvents necessitates high H2 pressures to ensure efficient reaction progress. This requirement not only adds operational complexity but also increases energy demands, particularly due to the energy-intensive process of compressing H2 gas and maintaining high-pressure conditions. Furthermore, in industrial production, approximately 96% of H2 is derived from fossil resources, presenting challenges such as high production costs, difficulties in gas storage and transportation, and associated safety risks [17]. As fossil energy sources continue to deplete, researchers are increasingly focusing on non-exogenous H2 as a hydrogen source, with alcohol replacing corrosive formic acid as a major component in non-exogenous hydrogen systems [18–22]. Catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) reactions utilizing alcohols as non-exogenous hydrogen sources primarily follow two pathways: the metal hydride route and the Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley (MPV) route (Table S1, Entries 17–44) [23–25]. The key distinction between these pathways is whether the β-H of alcohols is transferred to the carbonyl carbon of the substrate adsorbed on the catalyst surface during the hydrogen transfer process [24,26,27]. The MPV route predominantly involves Lewis acid and basic sites, while the metal hydride route is significantly influenced by metal sites and adequate basic sites [24,28,29]. Research on the MPV route for converting γ-valerolactone (GVL) from ethyl levulinate (EL) using alcohols as hydrogen sources has increased rapidly in recent years [25,30,31]. However, studies focusing on the metal hydride route for the CTH of EL with alcohols as hydrogen sources remain limited, particularly systematic studies, whether using noble or non-noble metals (Table S1, Entries 45–47) [32–34]. In the metal hydride route for producing GVL from EL, the primary metals used are Ru, Zn, or Co species [32–34]. Meanwhile, Cu-based catalysts have also been employed in the metal hydride route for converting methyl levulinate (ML) to GVL and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-dimethylfuran, owing to their lower cost and favorable performance [35–38]. However, due to their susceptibility to reduction, Cu0 species may already be present during catalyst preparation (Table S2, Entries 1–2) [35–37]. Furthermore, Cu2+/Cu+ species can undergo in situ reduction to Cu0 by hydrogen generated from donor solvents (e.g., MeOH or 2-PrOH) during the reaction, which may negatively affect the stability and selectivity—especially over multiple cycles (Table S2, Entries 1–2) [35–37]. The widespread research on the MPV route can be attributed to the high thermochemical stability of the catalytic system, its accessibility and cost-effectiveness, the low cost of hydrogen donors, and the high selectivity for the target product [31]. Although the metal hydride route for catalyzing EL to GVL shows similar potential to the MPV route, it underscores the need for further investigation in this area. Studies have shown that the incorporation of Mg2+ or Zr4+, which exhibit strong positive charges, can stabilize Cu+ species via electronic interactions [37,39]. Building on the overview and analysis of various catalytic routes for converting EL to GVL (Table S1) and related reports [35–37,39], this study synthesized a series of CuMgZrOx catalysts via a simple co-precipitation method for the metal hydride route of converting EL to GVL, employing 2-PrOH as an economical hydrogen donor. Systematic comparisons indicate that the synergy among Cu, Mg, and Zr not only facilitates the stabilization of Cu2+/Cu+ species (Table S2, Entry 3) but also provides abundant basic sites, resulting in robust activity and excellent stability. These findings provide an important reference for extending the metal hydride route in biomass valorization. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, urea, MeOH, n-BuOH, and 2-BuOH were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (China). Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, and EtOH were purchased from Xilong Science Co., Ltd. (China). Zr(NO3)4·5H2O and 2-PrOH were obtained from Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. (China). n-PrOH was purchased from Aladdin reagents Co., Ltd. (China). All reagents mentioned above are of analytical grade. EL (99%), ML (98%), and butyl levulinate (BL, 98%) were obtained from Shanghai Yien Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. (China). GVL (98%) was obtained from Aladdin reagents Co., Ltd. (China). 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts Dissolve a certain quantity of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and Mg(NO3)2·6H2O in 100 mL of deionized water. After 10 min of ultrasonication, a precise quantity of Zr(NO3)4·5H2O was ultrasonicated for an additional 5 min to achieve a specific mole ratio of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O: Mg(NO3)2·6H2O: Zr(NO3)4·5H2O (1:1.15:2). A certain amount of urea was dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water and subsequently added to the above salt solution. The mixed solution was placed on a thermostatic magnetic stirrer, heated in a water bath, and hydrolyzed at 90 °C for 4 h under atmospheric pressure with continuous stirring at 320 rpm. After hydrolysis, the suspension was aged for 2 h at 90 °C. After cooling to room temperature, the blue gelatinous precipitate was separated using a filter and dried in an oven at 110 °C for 24 h. The dried solid was ground, sieved, and calcined at 400 °C in a muffle furnace for 4 h with a heating rate of 10 °C/min to yield the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst. The same method was used to synthesize other ternary metal oxides. The Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalyst, however, was not calcined at 400 °C but was reduced at 400 °C for 4 h in a 5% hydrogen atmosphere under the same conditions. By adjusting the active metal precursors to Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and Zr(NO3)4·5H2O and varying the Cu(NO3)2·3H2O: Zr(NO3)4·5H2O molar ratio to 1:2 and 1:3, binary metal catalysts, denoted as Cu1Zr2Ox and Cu1Zr3Ox, were synthesized using the same method employed for Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst synthesis. This approach was also applied to obtain other binary metal oxides. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts 2.3.1 XRD The XRD patterns of the catalysts were obtained using a Mini Flex 600 X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan). The energy mode was set to standard, using Cu-Kα as the radiation source, with an operating voltage of 40 kV and an operating current of 30 mA. The scanning range was set to 2θ from 10° to 80°, and the scanning speed was 10°/min. 2.3.2 SEM and energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS) The catalysts were fixed with conductive adhesive and sputter-coated with gold. The surface morphology of the catalysts was observed using a Regulus 8100 (Hitachi, Japan) field emission SEM. EDS was used to obtain the elemental mapping. 2.3.3 TEM The catalyst was dispersed in anhydrous ethanol and subjected to ultrasonic treatment, then fixed with conductive adhesive. TEM images of the catalyst were obtained using Talos F200S equipment (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). Elemental mapping was performed using the SUPER X system. 2.3.4 XPS and AES XPS and AES (Auger electron spectroscopy) were measured using the ESCALAB 250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA), with the C 1s binding energy (284.8 eV) used as the calibration reference. 2.3.5 Specific surface area, pore size distribution, and pore volume The specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution of the catalysts were measured using an ASAP 2460 analyzer (Micromeritics, USA). Initially, the catalyst was loaded into a sample tube and pretreated by heating in a vacuum at 300 °C for 3 h. Afterward, N2 gas was passed through the sample to obtain N2 adsorption isotherms and calculate the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution of the catalysts. 2.3.6 H2-TPR H2-TPR was performed using a BSD-Chem C200 automatic chemisorption instrument (Beishide Instrument-ST, China). The testing procedure was as follows: First, in an Ar atmosphere, the temperature was ramped up to 300 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, followed by a 1 h pretreatment to remove any gases adsorbed on the surface. Then, under an H2/Ar atmosphere (10 vol% H2) with a flow rate of 20 mL/min, the temperature was increased at a rate of 10 °C/min to 800 °C, and data were recorded over the temperature range of 100–800 °C. 2.3.7 CO2-TPD The basic sites of the catalyst were determined using CO2 as a probe molecule on the TP-5080 chemisorption analyzer. The test procedure was as follows. The catalyst was placed in a quartz tube, heated from room temperature to 300 °C under a He atmosphere (30 mL/min) at a rate of 10 °C/min, and pretreated for 1 h before cooling to 100 °C. CO2/He (10 vol% CO2) gas was then introduced for adsorption until saturation. Afterward, He (30 mL/min) was used to purge the physically adsorbed CO2 until a stable baseline was achieved. Temperature-programmed desorption was then carried out under He (30 mL/min) at a heating rate of 10 °C/min, with data recorded up to 900 °C. 2.3.8 Py-FTIR The acid properties of the catalyst were evaluated using Py-FTIR on a Bruker Tensor 27 FTIR spectrometer. The catalyst was first degassed under vacuum at 200 °C for 3 h, then cooled to room temperature before pyridine adsorption. The infrared spectrum was recorded after heating the samples to 150 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and maintaining that temperature for 1 h, within the range of 1400–1700 cm-1. 2.3.9 ICP-OES After the catalytic reaction, the reaction solution underwent acid digestion pretreatment, and the leaching of metal elements in the solution was detected using a 700 Series ICP-OES (Agilent Technologies, USA). 2.3.10 Carbon deposition analysis Carbon deposition on the catalyst was analyzed using a Vario El cube elemental analyzer (Elementar, Germany). Before testing, the catalyst was vacuum-dried at 80 °C for 2 h. 2.4 Experimental procedures All reactions were conducted in a 100 mL mechanically stirred reactor (Anhui Kemi Machinery Technology Co., Ltd., China). The typical experimental procedure was as follows: 1 g of EL, 19 g of 2-PrOH, and a specified amount of solid catalyst were added to the reactor vessel. The sealed reactor was heated to the desired temperature, and the reaction proceeded under autogenic pressure with vigorous stirring at 500 rpm. After the designated reaction time, the reaction was stopped, and the reactor vessel was cooled to room temperature. 2.5 Product analysis Liquid products were quantitatively analyzed using a GC-2014C gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with a WondaCap5 column (30.0 m × 0.25 µm × 0.25 mm). The specific analysis conditions were as follows: injector temperature was set at 250 °C, the initial column temperature at 40 °C, followed by a temperature ramp of 15 °C/min to a final column temperature of 240 °C. The detector temperature was set to 270 °C. A portion of the liquid product was transferred to a centrifuge tube and centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 1 min. Concentrations of various components were calculated based on standard curves. EL, ML, and BL conversions, GVL yield and selectivity, as well as carbon balance, were calculated using the following formulas. (1) GVL yield ( % ) = Mole of GVL in the products Initial mole of EL/ML/BL × 100 % (2) EL/ML/BL conversion (%) = ( 1 - Mole of EL/ML/BL in the products Initial mole of EL/ML/BL ) × 100% (3) GVL selectivity (%) = GVL yield EL/ML/BL conversion × 100 % (4) Carbon balance (%) = Output of catbon Input of carbon × 100 % Qualitative analysis of liquid products was conducted using a GC–MS-QP2020NX analyzer (Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with an SH-Rxi-5SilMS column (30.0 m × 0.25 µm × 0.25 mm). All other analysis conditions were consistent with the above GC analysis. Gas products generated during the reaction were analyzed using a Trace 1300 GC (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) equipped with a JN.OV-1301 column (30.0 m × 1.2 µm × 0.32 mm) and a thermal conductivity detector. The column temperature was set at 60 °C and held for 5 min. Qualitative analysis of the gases (CO2, O2, CH4, and H2) components was performed by comparing GC curves with standard gas samples. All yield and conversion reported in this study were derived from a minimum of three independent experiments conducted under identical conditions. The range of variation for these measurements was maintained within ±3%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts 3.1.1 SEM SEM images of the catalysts were shown in Fig. S1 (a–d), revealing significant differences in morphology. The addition of Mg during the synthesis of the Cu1Mg1.15Ox catalyst resulted in smaller and uniformly dispersed particles without any agglomeration (Fig. S1b). This indicates that the inclusion of MgO can significantly enhance the dispersion of Cu species, likely due to its high specific surface area. These findings are consistent with XRD and BET analysis, as well as reports in the literature [40,41]. In contrast, the Cu1Zr2Ox catalyst without Mg doping, showed large agglomerates on its surface, suggesting inadequate dispersion, non-homogeneous particle sizes, and irregular morphologies (Fig. S1c). For the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst, a morphology similar to Cu1Mg1.15Ox catalyst was observed, but with slightly larger particle size (Fig. S1d), further demonstrating the dispersing effect of Mg species. SEM-EDS analysis showed a uniform distribution of O, Cu, Mg, or Zr elements in the Cu1Mg1.15Ox, Cu1Zr2Ox, and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalysts (Fig. S1, e–g). The Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst exhibits smaller particle sizes and a uniform distribution of active components, promoting better contact between the catalyst and substrate, which leads to higher catalytic activity during the reaction process [42]. 3.1.2 XRD In the Cu1Mg1.15Ox catalyst, characteristic peaks at 2θ of 35.5° and 38.9° corresponded to CuO diffraction peaks (PDF#48–1548), while those at 2θ of 42.9° and 62.4° corresponded to MgO diffraction peaks (PDF#45–0946) (Fig. 1 a). As shown in peaks of CuO and Cu1Mg1.15Ox, MgO addition reduced the intensity of CuO peaks, indicating that an appropriate amount of MgO promoted CuO dispersion, resulting in lower peak intensity (Fig. 1a) [43]. In the Cu1Mg1Zr1Ox, Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox, and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalysts, characteristic diffraction peaks of CuO, MgO, and ZrO2 were observed (Fig. 1a). Notably, compared to the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalyst, CuO2 and Cu peaks were absent in the Cu1Mg1Zr1Ox and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalysts, indicating that at a reduction temperature of 400 °C, Cu species in the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) had been partially reduced to CuO2 and Cu. In the Cu1Mg1.15Zr3Ox catalyst, only diffraction peaks similar to ZrO2 were observed (PDF#49–1642), with characteristic peaks at 2θ = 30.1°, 50.2°, and 59.7°, corresponding to the (111), (220), and (311) planes of ZrO2, respectively. No CuO and MgO peaks were observed, possibly due to the low loading and high dispersion of CuO and MgO in the Cu1Mg1.15Zr3Ox catalyst [44,45]. 3.1.3 XPS and AES XPS analysis was conducted to determine the chemical composition of Cu1Zr2Ox, Cu1Mg1.15Ox, Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox, and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalysts, as shown in Fig. 1(b–g). The full-scan XPS spectra revealed the presence of elements Cu, Mg, Zr, or O, confirming the successful synthesis of the catalysts (Fig. 1b). The high-resolution C 1s spectra displayed three characteristic peaks at binding energies of approximately 284.8 eV, 286.2 eV, and 288.7 eV, corresponding to C−C, C−O, and C=O, respectively (Fig. 1c). The high-resolution Mg 1s spectra of Cu1Mg1.15Ox, Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox, and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalysts indicated MgO presence (Fig. 1d). Peaks at binding energies of 181.7 eV and 184.1 eV for the Cu1Zr2Ox, Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox, and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalysts, were assigned to Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2, corresponding to Zr4+ in ZrO2 (Fig. 1e). In the high-resolution O 1s spectra (Fig. 1f), peaks corresponding to metal oxides, CO3 2−, and C=O were observed, confirming the presence of metal oxides in the Cu1Zr2Ox, Cu1Mg1.15Ox, Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox, and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalysts [46]. The high-resolution Cu 2p spectra of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1g. The binding energies of Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 were attributed to Cu2+, indicating that Cu2+ was the chemical state of Cu species in the Cu1Zr2Ox, Cu1Mg1.15Ox, and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalysts [47]. The satellite peaks for Cu 2p3/2 in these catalysts appeared around 941.0 eV and 943.6 eV, while the Cu 2p1/2 satellite peak was approximately 962.0 eV, further supporting the presence of Cu2+ in these catalysts [48,49]. Notably, the binding energies of Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 in the Cu1Zr2Ox catalyst were approximately 933.7 eV and 953.5 eV, respectively. In contrast, in the Cu1Mg1.15Ox and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalysts, the binding energies of Cu 2p3/2 increased to 934.1 eV and 934.9 eV, and those of Cu 2p1/2 increased to 953.8 eV and 954.6 eV. This was attributed to the strong interaction between the introduced MgO and Cu species, which inhibited the leaching of metal species in the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst, enhancing its cycle stability and preventing the complete reduction of Cu species [38]. The high-resolution Cu 2p spectrum of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalyst showed binding energies of approximately 933.8 eV and 954.1 eV for Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 (Fig. 1g), with only weak satellite peaks observed. Cu 2p emission lines were fitted with two Gaussian peaks, representing Cu2+ and Cu0/Cu+. In addition, in the Cu LMM Auger spectrum of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalyst, peaks at kinetic energy (KE) of 917.7 eV and 916.8 eV corresponded to CuO and Cu2O, while the peak at 918.6 eV corresponded to metallic Cu (Fig. 1h) [50]. NLLSF peak fitting showed that the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalyst contained Cu0, Cu+, and Cu2+, whereas the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst showed only Cu2+ (Fig. 1h). This indicates the presence of Cu0, Cu+, and Cu2+ in the hydrogen-reduced Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalyst, with Cu0 being the predominant state. The Cu LMM Auger spectra results further corroborated the distribution of the Cu2+ state or Cu+ state observed in the XRD analysis (Fig. 1a). 3.1.4 TEM The TEM image of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst showed that the catalyst consisted of nanoparticles (Fig. 2 a). The high-resolution TEM image revealed lattice spacings of 0.26 nm and 0.28 nm, corresponding to the (200) and (111) planes of ZrO2, respectively (Fig. 2b) [51]. In addition, lattice spacing of 0.27 nm and 0.24 nm were observed for CuO and MgO, respectively (Fig. 2b) [52,53]. The Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst was identified as a composite oxide catalyst, with its primary phase consisting of CuO, ZrO2, and MgO, consistent with the XPS analysis. The average particle size of the nanoparticles, determined from the Gaussian-fitted particle size distribution plot (Fig. 2c), was approximately 24.2 nm. Particle size distribution was relatively uniform, with most particles falling in the 20–30 nm range. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of the catalyst displayed diffraction rings corresponding to various ZrO2 crystal planes (Fig. 2d), with no clear diffraction rings for CuO and MgO [54]. This phenomenon can be attributed to the small size and high dispersion of CuO and MgO nanoparticles. Elemental mapping (Fig. 2e) further showed a uniform distribution of Cu, Mg, Zr, and O elements, with minimal fluctuation, consistent with the SEM-EDS results. TEM analysis confirmed that the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst consisted of uniformly distributed nanoparticles, with uniform metal element distribution, which is advantageous for achieving higher catalytic activity. 3.1.5 Specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution The structural characteristics of the Cu1Mg1.15Ox and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalysts, including specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution, were investigated using N2 adsorption–desorption experiments, and the results are presented in Table S3. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the Cu1Mg1.15Ox and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalysts correspond to Type IV isotherms (Figs. S2a and b) [55,56], show significant hysteresis in the adsorption–desorption loops. The pore size distribution indicates that the primary pore sizes range from 2 nm to 50 nm, confirming the mesoporous nature of the catalysts (Figs. S2c and d) [57]. In Fig. S2(c), the Cu1Mg1.15Ox catalyst shows a broad pore size distribution, with peaks at 2.8 nm and 28.3 nm, indicating a substantial presence of mesopores. The peak at 28.3 nm was more intense, suggesting that the pore distribution is primarily concentrated in the 20–36 nm range, with a prevalence of larger pores. However, with the addition of ZrO2, the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst exhibited fewer large pores, and the ZrO2 modification led to a more uniform and narrower pore size distribution (Fig. S2d). The Cu1Mg1.15Ox catalyst exhibited a specific surface area of 89.7 m2/g, pore volume of 0.4 cm3/g, and average pore size of 16.3 nm (Table S3). In comparison, the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst showed a slightly reduced specific surface area of 84.7 m2/g, a decreased pore volume of 0.07 cm3/g, and a significantly smaller average pore size of 3.3 nm (Table S3). These changes can be attributed to the inclusion of ZrO2, which occupied some of the porous channels initially present in the Cu1Mg1.15Ox catalyst [58]. The relatively high specific surface area of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst is primarily attributed to the introduction of MgO, which is also consistent with SEM and XRD analyses [40,41]. In addition, the catalytic activity per unit surface area was calculated and included in Table S4 for both catalysts, considering both substrate conversion and product yield. The Cu1Mg1.15Ox and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalysts exhibited similar catalytic activities of 0.084 mmol/(m2·h) based on substrate conversion under the same reaction conditions. However, when based on product yield, the catalytic activity of Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox reached 0.068 mmol/(m2·h), significantly higher than the 0.052 mmol/(m2·h) of Cu1Mg1.15Ox. This value is approximately 1.31 times greater, reflecting the superior efficiency of Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox in selectively converting EL to GVL. In summary, the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst is a mesoporous material with a large specific surface area and small pore size. The combination of its appropriate surface area and uniformly distributed pore structure contributes to efficient substrate-to-active-site interactions, which likely enhances catalytic performance. Catalysts with smaller pores are often more effective for converting small molecules like EL [59]. This is possible because small molecules spend less time in the larger pores of the catalyst, which can hinder effective contact between the substrate and active sites, thus reducing catalytic activity [59]. 3.1.6 H2-TPR The variation in reduction temperatures is primarily associated with the intensity of interactions between the metal oxides [60]. The H2-TPR spectra in Fig. 3 (a) revealed a reduction peak for the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst, attributed to CuO reduction, indicating that Cu2+ is the primary form of Cu in the catalyst, consistent with the XPS, LMM Auger, XRD, and TEM analyses [60,61]. MgO and ZrO2 are oxides known for their resistance to reduction, showed no reduction peaks up to 600 °C in the Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst (Fig. 3a). The Cu1Zr3Ox catalyst exhibited reduction peaks at 149.2 °C, 199 °C, and 438.4 °C (Fig. 3a). The 149.2 °C peak was attributed to the reduction of dispersed Cu species on the surface, while the higher temperature peak at 199 °C was associated with the reduction of agglomerated CuO [62,63]. The peak area at 199 °C was smaller than that at 149.2 °C, indicating a lower content of agglomerated CuO [62,63]. The reduction peak at 438 °C likely corresponded to Cu2O reduction, which requires a higher reduction temperature due to its higher apparent activation energy compared to CuO [60,64]. In addition, electronic interactions between Zr species and CuOx may facilitate the formation of a stable Cu+ state [37,60,64]. The Cu1Mg1.15Ox catalyst exhibited a broader, more pronounced reduction peak at lower temperatures (100–200 °C) than the Cu1Zr3Ox catalyst. In addition, the reduction temperature of Cu2O in Cu1Mg1.15Ox was higher (521 °C) than in Cu1Zr3Ox (438 °C), suggesting a stronger interaction between MgO and Cu species, consistent with XPS analyses [65]. In addition, the CuO reduction peak in the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst, at 226.5 °C, was higher than those in Cu1Zr3Ox and Cu1Mg1.15Ox, indicating that CuO in Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox was more resistant to reduction. LMM Auger and XRD characterizations further confirmed that the oxidation state of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst was Cu2+ state, which was gradually reduced through in-situ generated hydrogen during the cycling experiments at 240 °C, maintaining the Cu+ state. In the metal hydride route of the CTH process, maintaining the Cu2+/Cu+ state is essential for the dehydrogenation of 2-PrOH and the hydrogenation of C=O, which are crucial for achieving high yields of the desired product [28,29,37]. In addition, the increased reduction resistance also suggested stronger inter-metallic interactions within Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox, contributing to enhanced catalytic stability. 3.1.7 CO2-TPD The total basicity and basic strength distribution of the CuO, MgO, ZrO2, Cu1Zr2Ox, Cu1Mg1.15Ox, Mg1.15Zr2Ox, and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalysts were determined by CO2-TPD, as shown in Table 1 and Fig. 3(b–h). Typically, three types of CO2 desorption peaks appear in TPD analysis, corresponding to weak, medium, and strong basic sites. All catalysts exhibited noticeable desorption peaks. Desorption peaks observed at 100–350 °C, 350–600 °C, and above 600 °C correspond to weak, medium, and strong basic sites, respectively. Peak-fitting results are shown in Fig. 3(b–h). CuO primarily contains medium basic sites, MgO mainly features weak basic sites, while ZrO2 exhibits both weak and medium basic sites. Among the binary oxides, Cu1Mg1.15Ox shows relatively low levels of all types of basic sites. Cu1Zr2Ox mainly contains weak basic sites, with fewer medium sites, while Mg1.15Zr2Ox exhibits a higher content of weak and medium sites, possibly due to the interaction between Mg species and Zr species leading to a higher content of weak and medium sites. In the ternary metal oxide, Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox also shows a high content of basic sites, with a distribution similar to Mg1.15Zr2Ox. The quantitative results are provided in Table 1. Among the single metal oxides, CuO has the lowest total basicity (0.2540 mmol/g), followed by MgO (0.2971 mmol/g), with ZrO2 having the highest total basicity (0.4134 mmol/g). Cu1Mg1.15Ox and Cu1Zr2Ox show relatively low total basicity at 0.0719 mmol/g and 0.1841 mmol/g, respectively. Mg1.15Zr2Ox exhibits the highest total basicity among all the catalysts (1.0115 mmol/g), while Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox has a slightly lower total basicity of 0.8821 mmol/g. This suggests that interactions between Mg species and Zr species significantly enhance the total basicity of the catalyst. According to AES analysis, Cu species in the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst predominantly exist in the Cu2+ state (Fig. 1h). CO2-TPD analysis further revealed that the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst possesses a high density of basic sites (Table 1, Entry 7). Relevant literature indicates that the Cu2+/Cu+ state exhibits the highest dehydrogenation activity at adequate basic sites, promoting conversion to the target product via the metal hydride route [28,29]. Specifically, with 2-PrOH as the solvent, Cu(II) or Cu(I), rather than metallic Cu, is more effective at undergoing dehydrogenation at adequate basic sites, which enhance the deprotonation capability of 2-PrOH, and preferentially adsorbs hydrogen species for the C=O hydrogenation process [28,37,66,67]. In addition, basic sites could also assist the lactonization reaction [68]. Poisoning experiments further demonstrate the critical role of basic sites in the conversion of EL to GVL. Based on the above analysis, it can be concluded that the Cu2+/Cu+ state, as well as sufficient basic sites in the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst, play a significant role in the transformation of EL to GVL through the metal hydride route. 3.1.8 Py-FTIR The acidity types of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst were determined using Py-FTIR, as shown in Fig. 3(i). Peaks around 1444 cm-1 and 1608 cm-1 correspond to the characteristic absorption bands of Lewis acid sites [69], while peaks around 1540 cm-1 and 1630 cm-1 correspond to Brønsted acid sites [69,70]. The band at 1590 cm-1 corresponds to the 8a vibrational mode of pyridine linked by hydrogen bonding to hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface [69]. The amount of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites was 114.66 µmol/g and 5.02 µmol/g, respectively. The addition of Mg2+ species provides Lewis acid sites [39]. The incorporation of Zr4+ species into the catalyst can provide Lewis and Brønsted acid sites [71,72]. XPS and H2-TPR analyses indicate that Mg2+ and Zr4+ species are stably present. The introduction of Mg2+ or Zr4+, which possess strong positive charges, along with the Lewis acid sites provided by these species, can stabilize Cu+ species through electronic interactions [37,39]. The Brønsted acid sites assist in the lactonization of the ethyl 4-hydroxyvalerate (EHP, Fig. S3, GC–MS spectrum) intermediate to form GVL, while excessively strong Brønsted acid sites may lead to the ring opening of GVL [33,66,72,73]. A catalyst with an appropriate ratio of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites is beneficial for the conversion of levulinate esters to GVL [73]. 3.2 Catalyst screening for the transformation of EL to GVL A series of metal oxide catalysts were synthesized and tested under reaction conditions of 240 °C and 3 h. The most effective catalyst was selected for converting EL to GVL, with the results summarized in Table S5. A blank experiment was initially conducted, indicating that without a catalyst, using 2-PrOH as a hydrogen donor did not produce GVL (Table S5, Entry 1). The catalytic activity of monometallic and bimetallic metal oxides was then tested. Among the three monometallic catalysts, CuO, MgO, and ZrO2 could form GVL, but the yields were unsatisfactory, at 33.6%, 6.6%, and 43.0%, respectively (Table S5, Entries 2–4). The relatively high yield of GVL is attributed to the transfer hydrogenation capability by Zr or Cu species through the metal hydride route, with 2-PrOH as the solvent [66,74,75]. Next, binary (Table S5, Entries 5–12) and ternary (Table S5, Entries 13–19) metal oxide catalysts were synthesized and evaluated for the reaction. The influence of the basic sites of Cu-based catalysts on the GVL yield was compared (Fig. S4a). The conversion of Cu1Mg1.15Ox, Cu1Zr2Ox, and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox were almost identical (Fig. S4a). However, Cu1Mg1.15Ox has relatively low basic sites, while Cu1Zr2Ox exhibits more basic sites than Cu1Mg1.15Ox (Table 1), achieving GVL yields of 54.0% and 80.4%, respectively (Table S5, Entries 8 and 10). Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox possesses significantly more basic sites than Cu1Mg1.15Ox and Cu1Zr2Ox, similar to Mg1.15Zr2Ox, and achieves a GVL yield of 88.0% (Table S5, Entries 6, 8, 10, and 17). Besides, Mg1.15Zr2Ox, which contains no Cu2+/Cu+ state, has more basic sites than both Cu1Mg1.15Ox and Cu1Zr2Ox but achieves a lower GVL yield of 56.3% (Table 1; Table S5, Entry 6). These results indicate that, without sufficient basic sites and the synergistic effect with Cu2+/Cu+, the GVL yields obtained using single oxide catalysts (Table S5, Entries 2–4) and binary metal oxide catalysts (Table S5, Entries 5–12) did not meet the desired level. The catalytic activity of Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox was compared with other metal-based ternary catalysts. Cu1Mg1.15Zr1Ox, Cu1Mg1.15Zr3Ox, Ni1Mg1.15Zr2Ox, and Zn1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalysts achieved GVL yields of 81.0%, 81.7%, 78.7%, and 59.3%, indicating that Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox is the most active catalyst among the tested ternary metal catalysts. To compare the effects of different states of Cu species on hydrogen production and the reaction, Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (I) (physical mixture) and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) (H2 reduced) catalysts were prepared (Table S5, Entries 20–21). The comparison of gases potentially generated during the reaction process with standard gases (Fig. S5) indicates that hydrogen gas (H2) was produced during the reaction. Both the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalysts generated a small amount of H2, while the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (I) catalyst did not. The GVL yields of Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (I) and Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalysts were 22.3% and 24.5%, respectively (Table S5, Entries 20–21). The absence of H2 production and the lower catalytic activity of Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (I) could be attributed to the weaker interactions among the catalyst components due to physical mixing. These weaker interactions might have reduced the synergistic effects between the components, potentially resulting in a less favorable distribution or exposure of the Cu2+/Cu+ active sites, thus hindering effective catalytic reactions [37]. In addition, as shown by the Cu LMM Auger spectrum in Fig. 1(h), although most of the Cu species in the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalyst were reduced to Cu, the presence of Cu2+ state and Cu+ state still led to small amounts of H2 production. This occurs as Cu(II) or Cu(I) sites prefer to adsorb hydride species, which are generated from the dehydrogenation of 2-PrOH catalyzed by Cu2+ or Cu+ active sites at adequate basic sites, thereby promoting the metal hydride route of EL and facilitating the release of H2 [26,28,37,67]. When 2 MPa of H2 was introduced into the reactor, the yield of Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalyst approximately doubled, though it remained relatively low (Table S5, Entry 22). This increase in yield could be attributed to the introduction of H2, which promoted direct hydrogenation via metallic Cu rather than through a metal hydride route to form GVL [37,76,77]. In addition, to address concerns regarding near-complete conversion for certain catalysts in Table S5, additional experiments on the conversion of EL to GVL were conducted under lower catalyst loadings, i.e., under conditions of incomplete saturation conversion. The yields of the by-product isopropyl levulinate (IPL), formed via the transesterification of EL with 2-PrOH, and the by-product 1,4-pentanediol (1,4-PDO), generated through the ring-opening and hydrogenation of GVL, were also measured, as shown in Table S6. In Table S6, all tested catalysts produced IPL and a small amount of 1,4-PDO, except for Cu1Zr3Ox and Ni1Mg1.15Zr2Ox, which did not generate 1,4-PDO. The Cu1Zr2Ox catalyst showed the lowest 1,4-PDO yield at 1.9%, followed closely by the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst at 2.1%. The IPL yield of Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox was also relatively low, at 2.7%. Notably, the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst achieved the highest GVL yield (74.9%) and an exceptional carbon balance (87.0%), suggesting effective utilization of substrate carbon atoms with reduced by-product formation, while maintaining excellent catalytic activity. These results highlight the advantages of Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox as the most promising catalyst for this transformation. The influence of basic sites on the carbon balance and yield of Cu-based catalysts under unsaturated conversion was compared (Fig. S4b). Cu1Mg1.15Ox and Cu1Zr2Ox exhibit relatively fewer basic sites, resulting in lower carbon balance and yield. In contrast, Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox, with an ample amount of basic sites, achieves a notably higher carbon balance and yield. This improvement can be attributed to the reduction of undetectable by-products and the enhanced catalytic performance, as the ample basic sites in Cu-based catalysts play a crucial role in stabilizing intermediates and facilitating the desired reaction steps. The Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst (0.3 g) under unsaturated conversion was compared with other catalysts (0.5 g, unsaturated conversion) under the same conditions. As shown in Fig. S4(c), the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst achieves significantly higher conversion and yield than other catalysts, even with a smaller amount of catalyst, demonstrating the superior efficiency of this catalyst. This result also highlights that doping with Cu species markedly enhances the reaction and underscores the critical role of CuOx in improving both the conversion of EL and the yield of GVL. Characterization of Cu states (Fig. 1a, 1g, and 1h) and basic sites in Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox or Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) (Table 1), along with related reactions (Fig. S4, Tables S5 and S6), poisoning experiments (Section 3.5), and literature [28,37,66,67,77], suggests that the metal hydride route plays a dominant role in the CTH of EL to GVL over Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst. Based on these screening results, subsequent experiments focused on optimizing the reaction conditions and assessing the catalytic performance and cycling stability of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst. 3.3 Optimization of reaction conditions 3.3.1 Effect of reaction temperature on catalytic performance This section of the experiments initially investigated the effect of reaction temperature on the performance of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst, with temperatures ranging from 200 °C to 270 °C and a reaction time of 1 h. The changes in EL conversion, GVL selectivity, and GVL yield with temperature are depicted in Fig. 4 (a). At 200 °C, the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst achieved an EL conversion of 65.1% and a GVL yield of 47.6%. Increasing the temperature to 220 °C significantly improved EL conversion to 91.4% and boosted the GVL yield to 72.2%. As the reaction temperature increased to 240 °C, EL conversion gradually rose to 92.6%, and the GVL yield reached 75.1%. With the increase in reaction temperature from 200 °C to 240 °C, the yield of the target product GVL steadily rose, while the GC–MS revealed a corresponding decline in the peak of EHP, suggesting that EHP serves as an intermediate during the reaction process. This observation aligns with reports in the literature, which identify EHP as a key intermediate in the transformation of EL to GVL [33,78]. In general, the conversion of EL to GVL requires relatively high temperatures, as suitable elevated temperatures promote the transformation of intermediates and subsequent lactonization (Table S1). The higher temperature not only accelerated the conversion of EHP but also facilitated its subsequent lactonization to GVL, promoting the overall reaction [68,79]. However, as the temperature increased further, EL conversion continued to rise, but GVL yield decreased, possibly due to the formation of unidentified polymers at higher temperatures. At 270 °C, EL conversion reached 98.5%, but GVL yield dropped to 70.0%. Overall, the optimal reaction temperature for the metal hydride route of EL to GVL with the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst was determined to be 240 °C. 3.3.2 Effect of reaction time on catalytic performance At the optimal reaction temperature of 240 °C, the effect of reaction time on the performance of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst was further investigated. As shown in Fig. 4(b), extending the reaction time from 1 h to 3 h gradually increased EL conversion from 91.7% to 99.8%, with GVL yield rising from 77.3% to 88.0%. Extending the reaction time beyond 3 h had little effect on EL conversion (99.9% at both 4 h and 5 h). However, the GVL yield decreased after 3 h, dropping to 76.4% at 5 h. Based on quantitative analysis, the formation of the by-products IPL and 1,4-PDO over time is also examined (Fig. 4b). From 1 h to 2 h, the IPL yield increased from 3.9% to 6.2%, reflecting the progress of transesterification between EL and 2-PrOH. At 3 h, IPL decreased slightly to 5.0%, while a small amount of 1,4-PDO (2.2%) was detected for the first time. When the reaction was prolonged to 4 h and 5 h, 1,4-PDO yields increased to 2.5% and 3.1%, respectively, while GVL yields declined to 76.5% and 78.2%, and IPL slightly decreased to 4.7% and 4.5%. These results suggest that part of the GVL underwent ring-opening and subsequent hydrogenation to produce 1,4-PDO during prolonged reaction times, leading to a decrease in GVL yield. Although the IPL yield displayed an irregular trend over time, the transesterification of EL to IPL is also one of the factors contributing to the reduction in GVL yield. The carbon balance further supports these observations. As shown in Fig. 4b, the carbon balance increased from 89.5% at 1 h to 95.4% at 3 h, which corresponds to the optimal reaction time for achieving the highest GVL yield and selectivity. Beyond 3 h, the carbon balance decreased to 87.9% at 4 h and further to 84.1% at 5 h. This decline suggests that undetected by-products may be formed or that partial carbon loss occurs under prolonged reaction conditions. Therefore, considering all product distributions and the carbon balance, 3 h was determined to be the optimal reaction time for converting EL to GVL. The combination of high GVL yield (88.0%), selectivity (88.2%), and carbon balance (95.4%) at this time point underscores the efficiency of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst under these conditions. 3.3.3 Effect of catalyst dosage on catalytic performance The effect of catalyst dosage on EL conversion, GVL selectivity, and yield using the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst was explored, with dosages ranging from 0.2 g to 0.6 g at 240 °C, 3 h, and 500 rpm. As shown in Fig. 4(c), increasing the catalyst dosage from 0.2 g (20 wt%) to 0.5 g (50 wt%) enhanced both GVL selectivity and yield, reaching a maximum yield of 88.0% at 0.5 g (50 wt%). However, when the dosage was increased to 0.6 g (60 wt%), EL conversion and GVL yield decreased to 92.1% and 76.7%, indicating that excessive catalyst dosage negatively affects GVL yield. GC–MS analysis indicated that at 240 °C, excessive catalyst led to increased H2 generation, promoting the ring-opening hydrogenation of GVL to form the by-product 1,4-PDO, thus reducing GVL yield. Therefore, 0.5 g (50 wt%) was determined to be the optimal dosage, but 0.4 g (40 wt%) was selected for subsequent experiments due to only marginal sacrifice in GVL yield. 3.3.4 Effect of various hydrogen donors on catalytic performance The influence of various alcohols (MeOH, EtOH, n-PrOH, n-BuOH, 2-PrOH, and 2-BuOH) as hydrogen donors was explored under reaction conditions of 240 °C, 3 h, and 500 rpm (Fig. 4d). The effectiveness of hydrogen donors in the metal hydride route of the CTH process relies heavily on the reduction potential of the employed reducing alcohols. The reduction potential, ΔfH°, is defined as the difference of the standard molar enthalpy of formation between the alcohol and the corresponding carbonyl compound; namely, it represents the ease of hydrogen abstraction. Based on this definition, ΔfH° is inversely correlated with the hydrogen-donating ability of the alcohols [74,80]. In other words, a higher ΔfH° indicates a greater difficulty in abstracting hydrogen from the alcohol [74,80]. The reduction potentials of the alcohols investigated are ranked as follows: MeOH (130.1 kJ/mol) > n-PrOH (87.3 kJ/mol) > EtOH (85.4 kJ/mol) > n-BuOH (79.7 kJ/mol) > 2-PrOH (70.0 kJ/mol) > 2-BuOH (69.3 kJ/mol) [74,80]. Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox showed enhanced catalytic performance with secondary alcohols (2-PrOH and 2-BuOH) compared to primary alcohols (MeOH, EtOH, n-PrOH, and n-BuOH), primarily due to the lower reduction potential of secondary alcohols. When using MeOH as the hydrogen donor, the catalytic activity dropped significantly, yielding only 27.5% GVL due to the high reduction potential of MeOH. In contrast, secondary alcohols demonstrated stronger hydrogen-donating capabilities. Using 2-BuOH as the hydrogen donor, the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst achieved 94.3% EL conversion and 58.7% GVL yield. Among n-BuOH and 2-PrOH, 2-PrOH provided the highest catalytic efficiency, with a GVL yield of 88.0%. Although 2-PrOH has a slightly higher reduction potential than 2-BuOH, its increased steric hindrance may reduce adsorption on the catalyst surface and thereby lower its catalytic performance compared to 2-PrOH. 3.4 Cyclic stability 3.4.1 Cyclic stability at optimal yield The recycle stability of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst is a crucial indicator of the economic benefits of the catalytic reaction. Recycling tests were conducted to further assess its reusability and stability. After each cycle, the reaction solution was separated from the utilized catalyst by centrifugation, and the recovered catalyst was vacuum dried at 80 °C for 1 h before reuse. As shown in Fig. 4(e), after one cycle, the catalyst maintained 99.8% EL conversion and 86.4% GVL yield, with no significant decrease in activity compared to the fresh catalyst (99.7% EL conversion and 87.0% GVL yield). The catalytic performance remained stable in subsequent cycles. After seven cycles, the EL conversion and GVL yield were 99.7% and 83.1%, demonstrating that the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst has excellent reusability and stability, with at least seven cycles of effective use (Fig. 4e). Notably, the catalyst did not undergo any activation treatments such as air/oxygen calcination, ozone/nitrogen oxide oxidation, or gasification during the recycling tests. In organic solvents, carbon deposition during catalyst use is a key factor leading to activity decline. Carbon can cover the active sites or block pores, preventing substrate access to active sites—both being primary causes of catalyst deactivation [81,82]. In this study, an elemental analyzer was used to detect carbon content in the recovered catalyst. As shown in Table S7, after seven cycles, the carbon content of the recovered catalyst slightly increased to 3.2%, compared to 2.9% after one cycle. This analysis indicated that only a small amount of carbon deposition occurred during the recycling process, which did not significantly affect catalytic activity, demonstrating the excellent stability of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst. The leaching of active components from the catalyst is a key factor contributing to decreased catalytic activity [83,84]. A leaching experiment was conducted on the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst. As shown in Fig. 4(f), after 2 h of reaction, the catalyst was removed, and the reaction continued for an additional 3 h to evaluate whether any active species leached into the solution. The GVL yields almost no change after catalyst removal (Fig. 4f, solid red line), indicating negligible active catalytic species leached into the solution capable of promoting the reaction. Additionally, the solid black line in Fig. 4(f) represents the GVL yield with the catalyst present for 5 h. The GVL yield increased, peaked at 3 h, and subsequently decreased. This decline is primarily attributed to the potential occurrence of further ring-opening and hydrogenation reactions of GVL, which may lead to by-products such as 1,4-PDO, isopropyl valerate, or pentanoic acid [25,85,86]. To verify this, 1 g of GVL was used as the substrate under the same conditions for 2 h. After the reaction, by-products, such as 1,4-PDO, ethyl valerate, and isopropyl valerate, were detected, confirming the instability of GVL under these conditions and supporting the observed trend between 3–5 h in Fig. 4(f). In addition, the leaching of Cu, Mg, and Zr elements in the solution after 5 h of reaction was measured using ICP-OES, and the results are shown in Table S8. Cu content in the solution was 0.05 mg/kg (corresponding to 0.0011 wt% of the initial Cu amount), Mg content was 0.02 mg/kg (corresponding to 0.0010 wt% of the initial Mg amount), and Zr was not detected, likely because its concentration was below the detection limit (Table S8). These experiments indicate minimal leaching of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst, demonstrating excellent cycling stability. XRD characterization of the catalyst after multiple cycles revealed that after one cycle, a CuO diffraction peak was still observed at 2θ = 35.5°, along with a characteristic Cu2O peak at 2θ = 42.6° (PDF#34–1354). However, after two and three cycles, the 2θ = 35.5° peak disappeared, while the Cu2O peak remained (Fig. 4g). This indicated that after one cycle, a portion of the Cu2+ in the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst was reduced to Cu+ by in-situ generated hydrogen, and Cu2+ was completely reduced to Cu+ after two cycles. It is noteworthy that in a hydrogen atmosphere, reducing Cu2+/Cu+ to Cu0 is feasible at temperatures around 200–250 °C [87,88]. Experimental results demonstrated that the reduction of Cu2+/Cu+ to Cu0 of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox (II) catalyst could lead to a GVL yield of 24.5% with an EL conversion of 31.5%. The relevant discussion has been provided in Section 3.2. Nevertheless, the absence of Cu0 diffraction peaks suggested that the Cu+ state in the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst demonstrated excellent stability during recycling, as it did not undergo further reduction to Cu0 after the second cycles (Fig. 4g). A new MgO diffraction peak (PDF#45–0946) at 2θ = 42.9° was observed in the recycled catalyst, possibly due to a slight increase in MgO particle size during the cycling process. XPS analysis of the cycled Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst, shown in Fig. 5 (a), revealed the presence of Cu, Mg, Zr, and O species. The high-resolution C 1s spectra displayed typical peaks at 284.8 eV, 286.5 eV, and 288.7 eV, corresponding to C–C, C–O, and C=O (Fig. 5b). The binding energies of Mg 1s and Zr 3d in the cycled catalyst were consistent with the fresh catalyst (Fig. 5c and 5d). Similarly, the O 1s spectra revealed peaks associated with metal oxides, CO3 2-, and C=O, similar to the fresh catalyst (Fig. 5e), confirming the excellent stability of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst. Given the close binding energies of Cu0 and Cu+ in the Cu 2p3/2 region, Cu LMM Auger spectra were recorded to distinguish these species (Fig. 5f). KE peaks at 917.7 eV and 916.8 eV corresponded to CuO and Cu2O, while the 918.6 eV peak indicated elemental Cu [50]. As seen in Fig. 5(f), the fresh catalyst only displayed the CuO peak. After one cycle, both CuO and Cu2O peaks were observed, but after two and three cycles, only the Cu2O peak remained, with no Cu0 detected. The Cu LMM Auger spectra indicated that, after the first cycle, Cu2+ was partially reduced to Cu+, while some Cu2+ remained (Fig. 5f). After two cycles, Cu2+ was fully reduced to Cu+, which remained stable and did not further reduce to Cu0. The stable presence of Cu+ state is attributed to the electronic interactions between Zr species and CuOx, which likely promote the formation of a large number of stable Cu+ species, as well as the strong interaction between MgO and Cu species, making the reduction of Cu+ more difficult [37,60,64,65]. These findings from the Cu LMM Auger spectra (Fig. 5f) are consistent with the XRD results (Fig. 4g), confirming the stability of the Cu2+/Cu+ state during the cycling process. 3.4.2 Cyclic stability under conditions of incomplete saturation conversion Under conditions of incomplete saturation conversion (i.e., below 100% EL conversion), the stability of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst was investigated by comparing two scenarios: (i) catalyst present throughout the entire 1–5 h reaction, and (ii) catalyst removed after 2 h. Specifically, these experiments were conducted at 1 g EL, 19 g 2-PrOH, 0.25 g catalyst, 240 °C, and 500 rpm for reaction times ranging from 1 h to 5 h. When the catalyst remained in the reaction system (scenario ii, Fig. 4h, and Table S9 Entries 1–5), the EL conversion increased from 85.9% to 95.4% as the reaction proceeded from 1 h to 5 h, while the GVL yield initially rose significantly (55.4% to 69.5% at 1–3 h) but then declined markedly (69.5% to 56.2% at 3–5 h), indicating a notable decrease in catalytic performance over extended reaction times. Meanwhile, the yields of the by-products 1,4-PDO and IPL fluctuated only slightly from 3 h to 5 h, having a negligible effect on the overall product distribution. From 1 h to 3 h, the carbon balance progressively increased from 71.7% to 85.0%, likely due to the enhanced formation of GVL and fewer unidentified species. However, it subsequently decreased to 74.2% at 4 h and further to 66.2% at 5 h, suggesting that additional undetected by-products were produced or partial carbon loss occurred under prolonged conditions. In contrast, when the catalyst was removed after 2 h (scenario ii, Fig. 4h, and Table S9, Entries 6–8), the EL conversion remained approximately 88–89% between 3 h and 5 h, and the GVL yield remained between 64.9–66.3%. The formation of by-products 1,4-PDO and IPL was minimal under these conditions, with the carbon balance varying slightly (78.8–80.8%). These findings indicate that removing the catalyst after 2 h does not lead to significant changes in EL conversion or product distribution from 3 h to 5 h, highlighting negligible metal leaching under these conditions. This finding aligns with the leaching results observed under optimal yield conditions in Section 3.4.1, where the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst exhibited excellent resistance to metal loss. To further assess the cyclic stability under these non-saturated conversion conditions, a separate set of six consecutive cycle experiments was carried out at 1 g EL, 19 g 2-PrOH, 0.25 g catalyst, 240 °C, and 500 rpm for a fixed reaction time of 3 h (Table S10). As in Section 3.4.1, the catalyst was not subjected to any treatment during the recycling process. Over these six cycles, the EL conversion and GVL yield remained relatively high, decreasing slightly from 89.1% to 86.1% and from 69.5% to 64.3%, respectively. Meanwhile, the yields of 1,4-PDO and IPL exhibited minimal variation, and carbon balance deviations were consistently below 2.6%. These results underscore that the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst maintains robust stability and excellent resistance to deactivation across multiple cycles, even under incomplete saturation conversion conditions. The observed total yield decreases of about 5% over six cycles mirror the excellent cyclic stability demonstrated at optimal yield in Section 3.4.1, reinforcing that negligible metal leaching and minimal catalyst deactivation occur irrespective of reaction conversion levels. 3.5 Poisoning experiment In the reaction (1 g EL, 19 g 2-PrOH, 0.4 g catalyst, 240 °C, 3 h), equimolar amounts of 2,6-lutidine, pyridine, and benzoic acid were separately added as poisoning agents for Brønsted acid sites, Lewis acid sites, and basic sites [2]. The addition of 2,6-Lutidine and pyridine addition resulted in little change in EL conversion (99.0%), with GVL yields of 73.6% and 77.5%, indicating that both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites play a certain role in the reaction. A blank test under identical conditions but without EL showed that benzoic acid was almost unconverted, and only trace amounts of 2-PrOH were transformed into minor products. This result suggests that the esterification reaction between 2-PrOH and benzoic acid is unlikely to occur under these conditions. Instead, the observed decrease in GVL yield in the poisoning experiments is attributed to the deactivation of basic sites by benzoic acid rather than its reaction with 2-PrOH. When benzoic acid was added as a poisoning agent, the reaction achieved 77.7% EL conversion and 10.4% GVL yield, confirming that the basic sites are among the key active components. The poisoning experiments further demonstrate that the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, as well as the basic sites of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst, are crucial for achieving high catalytic activity, with the poisoning of basic sites having the greatest impact on performance. 3.6 Substrate-to-hydrogen donor ratio enhancement experiments Section 3.3 obtained optimal results with a substrate-to-hydrogen donor ratio of 1:19, yielding 99.8% EL conversion and 88.0% GVL after 3 h. Extending the reaction time beyond this point led to a decline in yield. To evaluate the performance of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst under conditions with reduced solvent usage, the substrate-to-hydrogen donor ratio was increased to 1:3 under optimal conditions and its impact on reaction performance was studied. Table S11 shows that after 3 h, EL was almost completely converted, yielding 69.7% GVL (Table S11, Entry 1). Extending the reaction time from 3 h to 5 h kept EL conversion constant but increased GVL yield from 69.7% to 78.3% (Table S11, Entries 1–2). These results suggest that at a substrate-to-hydrogen donor ratio of 1:3, extending the reaction time beyond 3 h can further increase yield. When extending the reaction time from 5 h to 7 h, EL conversion remained at 99.5%, with the yield reaching 90.0% (Table S11, Entry 3). The stability of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst under limited selectivity conditions (3 h reaction time) was also investigated. The catalyst was recovered post-reaction and vacuum-dried without calcination, yielding 69.2% GVL in the cycle test, nearly identical to the fresh catalyst (Table S11, Entries 1 and 4). These results indicate that even with a significantly increased substrate-to-hydrogen donor ratio, the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst maintained excellent yield and recyclability, demonstrating its potential for practical applications. 3.7 Exploration of reaction mechanism Based on the catalytic characterization (Sections 3.1) and screening experiments (Sections 3.2), effects of various reaction conditions (Sections 3.3), poisoning experiments (Section 3.5), and relevant literature, it is evident that the metal hydride route plays a dominant role in the catalytic conversion of EL to GVL over the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst [28,37,66,67]. In addition, intermediate detection in Section 3.3.1 identified EHP as an intermediate. Therefore, the proposed mechanism for the CTH of EL to GVL via the metal hydride route on the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst is shown in Scheme 1 . Initially, 2-PrOH adsorbs on the CuOx, where it loses β-H at the adequate basic sites provided by the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst, as discussed in Section 3.1.7, generating acetone and forming hydride species adsorbed on Cu(II) or Cu(I) sites (Scheme 1, Step 1) [26,28,37,66,67]. These species hydrogenate the carbonyl groups of EL, forming EHP and coupling with the release of H2 (Scheme 1, Step 2) [28,37,66,67]. Finally, an appropriate amount of Brønsted acid sites (supplied by Zr4+ species as discussed in Section 3.1.8) and basic sites, assist in the intramolecular nucleophilic attack of EHP, contributing to the lactonization reaction that leads to the formation of GVL (Scheme 1, Step 3) [33,66,68,72,73]. The Mg2+ and Zr4+ species in the catalyst possess strong positive charges, as discussed in Section 3.1.8. These charges provide Lewis acid sites that stabilize Cu+ species through electronic interactions, preventing further reduction and enabling the catalyst to maintain excellent activity throughout the cycle process [37–39]. 3.8 Effect of other substrates on the catalytic reaction The catalytic performance of the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst was evaluated using ML and BL as substrates for the metal hydride route of CTH reaction to GVL (Table S12 and Table S13). Blank experiments showed that without the catalyst and using 2-PrOH as the hydrogen donor, the conversions of ML and BL were 21.9% and 24.9%, respectively, with no GVL detected. In contrast, with the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst, ML achieved nearly complete conversion and a GVL yield of 87.2% at 240 °C for 3 h (Table S12, Entry 7), whereas BL required a higher temperature of 260 °C (for the same 3 h) to reach a comparable GVL yield of 83.7% (Table S13, Entry 8). At 240 °C and 3 h, the conversion and yield for BL (Table S13, Entry 8) were lower than for ML (Table S12, Entry 7) and EL, likely due to the increased steric hindrance with longer carbon chains in levulinate esters, requiring higher temperatures for efficient reactions. This steric hindrance negatively affected catalyst activity [89,90]. Based on the investigation of temperature, reaction time, and catalyst loading for EL, as well as relevant literature, the increase in levulinate ester conversion and GVL yield within the optimal temperature range can be attributed to enhanced reaction rates and more effective reduction of the carbonyl bond [90,91]. However, surpassing the optimal temperature leads to the formation of unidentified by-products via ring-opening reactions, thus lowering GVL yields [91]. Regarding reaction time, shorter durations result in incomplete conversion of substrates and intermediates, whereas excessively long times promote ring-opening and hydrogenolysis of GVL [90]. Concerning the catalyst loading, insufficient amounts provide fewer active sites, leading to lower conversion and yield. Conversely, excessive catalyst loading induces ring-opening reactions that decrease the GVL yield [90]. These findings confirm the versatility of Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox across various levulinate substrates, with 2-PrOH consistently outperforming other alcohols as hydrogen donor due to its favorable hydrogen-donating capability. 4 Conclusion This study synthesized CuMgZrOx ternary metal oxide catalysts by simple precipitation method with economical 2-PrOH as the hydrogen donor for the CTH of EL to GVL. The cost-effective Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst exhibits excellent physicochemical properties, achieving 99.8% EL conversion and 88.0% GVL yield. Studies have demonstrated that the presence of basic sites in the catalyst, combined with maintaining the Cu2+ state or Cu+ state, is vital for achieving high yields of GVL. Recycle experiments showed that after seven cycles, with only drying (no calcination), the catalyst maintained 99.7% EL conversion and 83.1% GVL yield. ICP-OES leaching tests showed minimal leaching of Cu and Mg at 0.05 mg/Kg and 0.02 mg/Kg, with no detectable Zr leaching. Carbon deposition analysis indicated that the catalyst had 2.9% carbon content after one cycle, increasing by just 0.3% after seven cycles. XRD and XPS analyses confirmed that the valence states of Mg and Zr remained stable. Cu LMM Auger spectroscopy confirmed that the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst was able to maintain Cu2+/Cu+ during the recycling process. Additionally, when the substrate-to-solvent ratio was optimized from 1:19 to 1:3, the GVL yield reached 90.0%, with nearly complete EL conversion, and the catalyst exhibited excellent stability in the recycling experiment, underscoring its potential for practical applications. A possible CTH mechanism for converting EL to GVL via the metal hydride as the dominant route was proposed based on thorough experimental studies and in-depth characterization. In the substrate versatility studies, the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst demonstrated outstanding performance, achieving over 99.7% conversion and 83.7% GVL yield with ML and BL. coredata.dc:description: The CuMgZrOx oxide catalysts were employed with economical 2-PrOH as the hydrogen donor for catalytic transfer hydrogenation of ethyl levulinate (EL) to γ-valerolactone (GVL). The cost-effective Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst exhibited excellent physicochemical properties, with 99.8% EL conversion and 88.0% GVL yield. Studies have shown that sufficient basic sites of the catalyst, along with the maintenance of the Cu2+/Cu+ state rather than Cu0, are crucial for achieving high GVL yields. Optimization of the substrate-to-hydrogen donor ratio (1:3), along with recycling tests and characterization, demonstrated excellent activity (99.5% EL conversion and 90.0% GVL yield) and cycle stability for the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst, highlighting its strong potential for practical applications. The mechanism for GVL production from EL via the metal hydride as the dominant route was proposed based on rigorous experimental studies and in-depth characterization. Substrate scope evaluation showed that the Cu1Mg1.15Zr2Ox catalyst also exhibited outstanding activity in converting methyl levulinate and butyl levulinate to GVL.
